title: Dear Coleen: My new man keeps walking out on me but then he comes grovelling back
text:

Dear Coleen

I’ve been seeing this man for about six months. It was instant attraction and he was the first guy I’d connected with since my divorce two years ago.

For the first month or so things were perfect, but then he started being around less and making excuses for why he couldn’t see me.

I knew he was carrying a lot of baggage from three previous marriages (yes, three!).

He claims his first wife was an alcoholic, his second cheated on him and that he married his third on

the rebound.

Then about three months into our relationship, he told me he was leaving me for someone else he’d known

a while.

I was shocked and hurt, but decided I had to move on, but two weeks later he came back with a grovelling apology and we got back together.

Since then, he’s walked out several times – it’s like he doesn’t know what he wants from one day to the next. I really like him, but I’m not sure I can cope with this constant uncertainty.

My grown-up kids think I’m mad to keep seeing him, but I just keep hoping he’ll get himself together.

What do you think?

Coleen says

I think your kids could be right! It doesn’t sound to me as if he’s never really known what he wants. Also, you’re only hearing one side of the story from him about why his marriages ended – and he ran into

the arms of someone else just three months into your relationship.

I know it’s hard when you have ­feelings for someone, but sometimes you have to wake up and put yourself first. He clearly has major commitment issues, which you’re very unlikely to be able to fix. In fact, he might need

years in therapy to work through his relationship issues.

It’s a very stressful way to live, always wondering when he’s going to walk out or come back – do you really want that for your future?

I think it’d be far easier to cut the ties now than a year or more down the line. And perhaps if it’s you who walks away – and you explain why you can’t carry on in the relationship – he’ll realise you are important to him and he does want to be with you. But don’t put your life on hold in the meantime.

I really think you need some proper time apart and you might find that you’re actually far happier on your own. After going through a divorce and making a new life for yourself, you deserve a lot better.
